text: A fuel pressure warning means for each engine, or a master warning means for all engines with provision for isolating the individual warning means from the master warning means.
classification_reason: Requires each aeroplane to have a specified fuel-pressure warning arrangement.

text: Fuel  indication system(s) which:
classification_reason: Mandates the installation of a qualifying fuel-indication system.

text: Provide(s) to the flight crew a full -time display of the total quantity of usable fuel on board;
classification_reason: Obliges the system to show the total usable fuel continuously.

text: Is (are) capable of indicating to the flight crew the quantity of usable fuel in each tank in accordance with [REF: CS 25.1337(b)];
classification_reason: Requires the system to display usable fuel in each tank.

text: Provide(s) fuel quantity and availability information to the flight crew, including alerts, to indicate any fuel  system condition (e.g. misconfiguration or failure) that, if not corrected, would result in no fuel being supplied to one or more engine(s). This includes:
classification_reason: Requires the system to give information and alerts on fuel availability problems.

text: Abnormal fuel transfer between tanks;
classification_reason: Lists abnormal fuel transfer as one of the conditions to be alerted; no standalone verb.

text: Trapped fuel;
classification_reason: Lists trapped fuel as an alert condition; supports the parent requirement.

text: Fuel leaks including in the engines .
classification_reason: Lists fuel leaks as an alert condition; completes the parent list.

text: Provide(s) a low fuel level cockpit alert for any tank and/or collector cell that should not become depleted of fuel. Each alert is such that:
classification_reason: Requires a low-fuel-level cockpit alert for specified tanks or cells.

text: It is provided to the flight crew when the usable quantity of fuel in the tank concerned reaches the quantity required to operate the engine(s) for 30 minutes at cruise conditions;
classification_reason: States the alert trigger point (30 minutes fuel remaining); no independent verb.

text: The alert and the fuel quantity indication for that tank are not adversely affected by the same single failure.  (See [REF: AMC 25.1305(a)(2)] )
classification_reason: Adds a design constraint on common-mode failures; supplements the parent clause.

text: An oil quantity indicator for ea ch oil tank.
classification_reason: Requires an oil-quantity indicator for each oil tank.

text: An oil pressure indicator for each independent pressure oil system of each engine.
classification_reason: Mandates an oil-pressure indicator for each independent oil system.

text: An oil pressure warning means for each engine, or a master warning means for all engines with provision for isolating the individual warning means from the master warning means.
classification_reason: Requires an oil-pressure warning means or master warning arrangement.

text: An oil temperature indicator for each engine.
classification_reason: Mandates an oil-temperature indicator for each engine.

text: Fire-warning devices that provide visual and audible warning.
classification_reason: Requires visual and audible fire-warning devices.

text: An augmentation liquid quantity indicator (appropriate for the manner in which the liquid is to be used in operation) for each tank.
classification_reason: Requires an augmentation-liquid quantity indicator for each relevant tank.

text: Reserved.
classification_reason: Paragraph is explicitly marked as reserved with no content.

text: For turbine engine -powered aeroplanes.  In addition to the powerplant instruments required by sub-paragraph (a) of this paragraph, the following powerplant instruments are required:
classification_reason: Defines that the following extra instruments apply to turbine-engine aeroplanes.

text: A gas temperature indicator for each engine.
classification_reason: Requires a gas-temperature indicator for each engine.

text: A fuel flow meter indicator for each engine.
classification_reason: Mandates a fuel-flow meter for each engine.

text: A tachomete r (to indicate the speed of the rotors with established limiting speeds) for each engine.
classification_reason: Requires a tachometer for the defined rotors of each engine.

text: A means to indicate, to the flight crew, the operation of each engine starter that can be operated continuously but that is neither designed for continuous operat ion nor designed to prevent hazard if it failed.
classification_reason: Requires an indicator showing operation of any continuously operable starter.

text: An indicator to indicate the functioning of the powerplant ice protection system for each engine.
classification_reason: Mandates an indicator for the powerplant ice-protection system.

text: An indicator for the fuel strainer or filter required by [REF: CS 25.997]  to indicate the occurrence of cont amination of the strainer or filter before it reaches the capacity established in accordance with [REF: CS 25.997(d)] .
classification_reason: Requires an indicator signalling contamination of the fuel strainer or filter.

text: A warning means for the oil strainer or filter required by [REF: CS 25.1019] , if it has no bypass, to warn the pilot of the occurrence of contamina tion of the strainer or filter screen before it reaches the capacity established in accordance with [REF: CS 25.1019(a)(2)] .
classification_reason: Requires a warning means for oil strainers or filters without bypass.

text: An indicator to indicate the proper functioning of any heater used to prevent ice clogging of fuel system components.
classification_reason: Mandates an indicator for heaters preventing ice clogging in the fuel system.

text: A vibration indication system that indicates unbalances in engine rotor systems and, when applicable, in propeller rotating assemblies.
classification_reason: Requires a vibration indication system for engine rotors and propeller assemblies.

text: For turbo -jet engine -powered aeroplanes.  In addition to the powerplant instruments required by sub -paragraphs (a) and (c) of thi s paragraph, the following powerplant instruments are required:
classification_reason: Specifies that the following additions apply to turbo-jet aeroplanes.

text: An indicator to indicate thrust, or a parameter that is directly related to thrust, to the pilot. The indication must be based on the direct measurement of thrust or of the parameters tha t are directly related to thrust. The indicator must indicate a change in thrust resulting from any engine malfunction, damage or deterioration. (See [REF: AMC 25.1305(d)(1)] .)
classification_reason: Requires a thrust or thrust-related parameter indicator that reflects engine condition.

text: A position indicating means to indicate to the flight crew w hen the thrust reversi ng device  ‚Äì
classification_reason: Mandates a position-indicating means for thrust-reversing devices.

text: Is not in the selected position, and
classification_reason: Describes the first state that must be indicated (not in selected position); no standalone verb.

text: Is in the reverse thrust position, for each engine using a thrust -reversing device.
classification_reason: Describes the second state that must be indicated (reverse-thrust position); no verb of its own.

text: For turbo -propeller -powered aeroplanes . In addition to the powerplant instruments required by sub-paragraphs ( a) and (c) of this paragraph, the following powerplant instruments are required:
classification_reason: States that the subsequent items apply to turbo-propeller aeroplanes.

text: A torque indicator for each engine.
classification_reason: Requires a torque indicator for each engine.

text: Position indicating means to indicate to the flight crew when the propeller blade angle is below the flight low pitch position, fo r each propeller.
classification_reason: Requires a position indication when propeller blade angle is below flight low-pitch.

text: Reserved
classification_reason: Paragraph is marked ‚ÄòReserved‚Äô with no requirements.

text: For aeroplanes equipped with fluid systems (other than fuel) for thrust or power augmentation , an approved means must be provided to indicate the proper functioning of that system to the flight crew.
classification_reason: Requires an approved indicator for any non-fuel fluid system used for thrust or power augmentation.

text: The following is required miscellaneous equipment:
classification_reason: States that the listed items are required equipment, creating the obligation for the aircraft to be fitted accordingly.

text: Reserved
classification_reason: The paragraph is explicitly marked ‚ÄúReserved‚Äù and contains no regulatory content.

text: Two or more independent sources of electrical energy.
classification_reason: Provides one specific item (independent electrical sources) that fulfils the preceding requirement but has no standalone verb of obligation.

text: Elect rical protective de vices, as prescribed in this CS -25.
classification_reason: Lists electrical protective devices as a required item, completing the parent sentence without its own mandatory verb.

text: Two systems for two -way radio communications, with controls for each accessible from each pilot station, designed and installed so that failure of one system will not preclude operation of the othe r system. The use of a common antenna system is acceptable if adequate reliability is shown.
classification_reason: Describes the required two-way radio communication systems as part of the parent obligation, but the directive force comes from the lead-in sentence.

text: Two systems for radio navigation, with controls for each accessible from each pilot station, designed and installed so that failure of one system will not prec lude operation of the other system. The use of a common antenna system is acceptable if adequate reliability is shown.
classification_reason: Specifies the required radio navigation systems, dependent on the preceding ‚Äòrequired equipment‚Äô statement rather than containing its own verb.

text: (See [REF: AMC 25.1309] ) The requirements of this paragraph, except as identified below, are applicable, in addition to specific design requirements of CS -25, to any equipment or system as installed in the aeroplane. Although this paragraph does not apply to the performance and flight characteristic requirements of Subpart B and the structural requirements of Subparts C and D, it does apply to any system on which compliance with any of those requirements is dependent. Jams of flight control surfaces or pilot controls covered by [REF: CS 25.671(c)(3)]  are excepted from the requirement s of [REF: CS 25.1309(b)(1)(ii)] . Certain single failures covered by [REF: CS 25.735(b)]  are excepted from the requirements of [REF: CS 25.1309(b)] . The failure conditions covered by [REF: CS 25.810]  and [REF: CS 25.812]  are excepted from the requirements of [REF: CS 25.1309(b)] . The requirements of [REF: CS 25.1309(b)]  apply to powerplant installations as specified in [REF: CS 25.901(c)] .
classification_reason: It explains where the paragraph applies and lists specific exclusions, thus defining the scope before any detailed rules.

text: (a) The aeroplane equipment and systems must be designed and installed so that:
classification_reason: Uses the word ‚Äúmust‚Äù to set a binding design obligation for equipment and systems.

text: (1) Those required for t ype certification or by operating rules, or whose improper functioning would reduce safety, perform as intended under the aeroplane operating and environmental conditions.
classification_reason: Lists a performance condition that completes the obligation in (a) but has no standalone "must."

text: (2) Other equipment and systems are not a source of danger in themselves and do not adversely affect the proper functioning of those covered by sub -paragraph (a)(1) of this paragraph.
classification_reason: Adds another outcome that the design in (a) must achieve, without introducing a new obligation word.

text: (b) The aeroplane systems and associated components, considered separately and in relation to other systems, must be designed so that -
classification_reason: States that systems "must be designed" to meet reliability targets, creating a direct obligation.

text: (1) Any catastrophic  failure condition
classification_reason: Introduces the catastrophic-failure branch of the parent requirement but has no independent modal verb.

text: (i) is extremely improbable; and
classification_reason: Specifies the first condition (extremely improbable) that fulfils the parent requirement.

text: (ii) does not result from a single failure; and
classification_reason: Gives the second condition (no single failure) under the same parent sentence.

text: (2) Any hazardous failure condition is extremely remote; and
classification_reason: Sets the probability target for hazardous failures, serving as a sub-condition of (b).

text: (3) Any major failure condition is remote; and
classification_reason: States the probability target for major failures, still tied to the parent "must be designed" obligation.

text: (4) Any significant latent failure is eliminate d as far as practical, or, if not practical to eliminate, the latency of the significant latent failure is minimised; and
classification_reason: Adds requirements on latent failures but remains subordinate to the main design mandate.

text: (5) For each catastrophic failure condition that results from two failures, either one of which is latent for more than one flight, it must be shown that:
classification_reason: Contains its own phrase "it must be shown that," creating a fresh obligation within the list.

text: (i) it is impractical to provide additional redundancy; and
classification_reason: Lists the first proof condition under the ‚Äúmust be shown‚Äù requirement without its own modal verb.

text: (ii) given that a single latent failure has occurred on a given flight, the failure condition is remote; and
classification_reason: Provides the second proof criterion, still reliant on the obligation in (b)(5).

text: (iii) the sum of the probabilities of the latent failure s which are combined with each evident failure does not exceed 1/1  000.
classification_reason: Gives the numerical probability limit, completing the proof conditions under (b)(5).

text: (c) Information concerning unsafe system operating conditions must be provided to the flight crew to enable them to take appropriate corrective action in a timely manner. Installed sys tems and equipment for use by the flight crew, including flight deck controls and information, must be designed to minimise flight crew errors which could create additional hazards.
classification_reason: Uses "must" twice to mandate crew information and error-minimising design features.

text: (d) Electrical wiring interconnection systems must be assessed in accordance with the requirements of [REF: CS 25.1709] .
classification_reason: Requires wiring to be assessed per another rule, using the obligatory word "must."

text: (e) Certification Maintenance Requirements must be established to prevent the development of the failure conditions described in [REF: CS 25.1309(b)], an d must be included in the Airworthiness Limitations Section of the Instructions for Continued Airworthiness required by [REF: CS 25.1529] .
classification_reason: Mandates establishing and listing Certification Maintenance Requirements, employing "must."

text: (See [REF: AMC 25.1310])
classification_reason: It only points the reader to AMC 25.1310 and contains no obligation or rule of its own.

text: (a) Each installation whose functioning is required for type certification or by operating rules and that requires a power supply is an "essential load" on the power supply. The power sources and the system must be able to supply the following power loads in p robable operating combinations and for probable durations (see [REF: AMC 25.1310(a)] ):
classification_reason: It states that the system "must" supply power for specified loads, which is a binding obligation.

text: (1) Loads connected to the system with the system functioning normally.
classification_reason: This item is merely one of the listed load conditions; it has no verb and completes the requirement in (a).

text: (2) Essential loads, after failure of any one prime mover, power converter, or energy storage device.
classification_reason: Like (1), it is a list entry describing a specific failure scenario without its own verb.

text: (3) Essential loads after failure of -
classification_reason: It introduces another load condition (‚Äòafter failure of‚Äô) but relies on the main verb in (a).

text: (i) Any one engine on two -engine aeroplanes; and
classification_reason: Sub-item further detailing the condition in (3) with no independent verb.

text: (ii) Any two engines on three -or-more engine aeroplanes.
classification_reason: Another sub-item expanding (3), still lacking its own operative verb.

text: (4) Essential loads for which an alternate source of power is required, after any failure or malfunction in any o ne-power supply system, distribution system, or other utilisation system.
classification_reason: Continues the list of load conditions and depends on the main requirement in (a).

text: (b) In determining compliance with sub -paragraphs (a)(2) and (3) of this paragraph, the power loads may be assumed to be reduced under a monitoring procedure consistent with safety i n the kinds of operation authorised. Loads not required in controlled flight need not be considered for the two -engine -inoperative condition on aeroplanes with three or more engines.
classification_reason: Gives permissive and exclusionary instructions (‚Äòmay be assumed‚Äô, ‚Äòneed not be considered‚Äô) on how to show compliance, making it binding text.

text: (See [REF: AMC 25.1315] ) No hazardous malfunction may occur as a result of the aeroplane being operated at the negative accelerations within the flight envelopes prescribed in [REF: CS 25.333] . This must be shown for the greatest duration expected for the acceleration.
classification_reason: It states an obligation that the aircraft must not experience hazardous malfunctions under specified negative accelerations and requires demonstration of compliance.

text: (See [REF: AMC 20-136])
classification_reason: This heading only points readers to AMC 20-136 and contains no mandatory language itself.

text: Each electrical and electronic system that performs a function whose failure would prevent the continued safe flight and landing of the aeroplane must be designed and installed so that:
classification_reason: It states that systems whose failure prevents safe flight ‚Äòmust be designed and installed so that‚Äô certain outcomes occur, establishing a binding obligation.

text: the function is not adversely affected during and after the time the aeroplane is exposed to lightning; and
classification_reason: It completes the parent ‚Äòmust be designed‚Äô sentence and has no standalone verb, simply listing one required outcome.

text: the system automatically recovers normal operat ion of that function, in a timely manner, after the aeroplane is exposed to lightning, unless the system‚Äôs recovery conflicts with other operational or functional requirements of the system that would prevent continued safe flight and landing of the aeropl ane.
classification_reason: Like (a)(1), it is just another listed outcome under the parent obligation and lacks its own ‚Äòmust‚Äô wording.

text: Each electrical and electronic system that performs a function whose failure would reduce the capability of the aeroplane or the ability of the flight crew to respond to an adverse operating condition must be designed and installed so that the f unction recovers normal operation in a timely manner after the aeroplane is exposed to lightning.
classification_reason: This sub-paragraph includes its own subject and ‚Äòmust be designed and installed‚Äô directive, imposing a direct obligation.

text: (See [REF: AMC 20-158])
classification_reason: This is just the section title that announces the subject (HIRF protection) before the detailed rules follow; it imposes no duty itself.

text: (a) Each electrical and electronic system that performs a function whose failure would prevent the continued safe flight and landing of the aeroplane must be designed and installed so that:
classification_reason: Contains the word ‚Äúmust‚Äù and tells designers how the most critical systems must be designed and installed.

text: (1) The function is not adversely affected during and after the time the aeroplane is exposed to HIRF  environment  I, as described in Appendix R ;
classification_reason: Item (1) finishes the sentence in (a) but has no independent ‚Äòmust‚Äô; it specifies one required design outcome.

text: (2) The system automatically recovers normal operation of that function, in a timely manner, after the aeroplane is exposed to HIRF environment  I, as described in Appendix R, unless the system‚Äôs recovery conflicts with other operational or functional requirements of the system that would prevent continued safe flight and landing of the aeroplane; and
classification_reason: Like (1), it adds another required outcome under the main ‚Äòmust‚Äô of paragraph (a) without stating a new obligation.

text: (3) The system is not adversely affected during and after the time the aeroplane is exposed to HIRF environ ment II, as described in Appendix R .
classification_reason: This list item continues the conditions that satisfy the single mandatory statement in (a).

text: (b) Each electrical and electronic system that performs a function whose failure would significantly reduce the capability of the aeroplane or the ability of the flight crew to respond to an adverse operating condition must be designed and installed so that the system is not adversely affected when the equipment providing the function is exposed to equipment HIRF test level 1 or 2, as described in Appendix R .
classification_reason: Uses ‚Äúmust‚Äù to set a separate binding design requirement for systems whose failure is significant but not catastrophic.

text: (c) Each electrical and electronic system that performs a func tion whose failure would reduce the capability of the aeroplane or the ability of the flight crew to respond to an adverse operating condition must be designed and installed so that the system is not adversely affected when the equipment providing the function is exposed to equipment HIRF test level 3, as described in Appendix R .
classification_reason: Again includes ‚Äúmust‚Äù and lays down a mandatory design standard for less critical systems.

text: Aeroplane equipment, systems and networks, considered separately and in r elation to other systems, must be protected from intentional unauthorised electronic interactions (IUEIs) that may result in adverse effects on the safety of the aeroplane. Protection must be ensured by showing that the security risks have been identified,  assessed and mitigated as necessary.
classification_reason: States an obligation with the word ‚Äúmust‚Äù to protect systems from unauthorised electronic interactions and to show risk mitigation.

text: When required by paragraph (a), the applicant must make procedures and Instructions for Continued Airworthiness (ICA) available that ensure that the security protections of the aeroplane‚Äôs equipment, systems and networks are maintained.
classification_reason: Imposes a duty on the applicant‚Äîusing ‚Äúmust‚Äù‚Äîto provide ICA procedures that preserve the required security protections.

text: (a) Each flight, navigation, and powerplant instrument for use by any pilot must be plainly visible to him from his station with the minimum practicable deviation from his normal position and line of vision when he is looking forward along the flight path.
classification_reason: It uses ‚Äúmust‚Äù to require that every relevant instrument be visible to the pilot, imposing a binding obligation.

text: (b) The flight instruments required by CS 25.1303  must be grouped on the instrument panel and centred as nearly as practicable about the vertical plane of the pilo t‚Äôs forward vision. In addition  ‚Äì
classification_reason: States that certain flight instruments ‚Äúmust be grouped‚Äù and centred, establishing a mandatory design rule.

text: (1) The instrument that most effectively indicates attitude must be on the panel in the top centre position;
classification_reason: Requires the attitude-indicating instrument to be in the top-centre, using the verb ‚Äúmust,‚Äù so it is an enforceable rule.

text: (2) The instrument that most effectively indicates airspeed must be adjacent to and directly to the le ft of the instrument in the top centre position;
classification_reason: Mandates the position of the airspeed instrument, containing its own subject and the word ‚Äúmust.‚Äù

text: (3) The instrument that most effectively indicates altitude must be adjacent to and directly to the right of the instrument in the top centre position; and
classification_reason: Sets a required location for the altitude instrument, expressed with ‚Äúmust,‚Äù making it compulsory.

text: (4) The instrument that most effectively indicates direction of flight must be adjacent to and directly below the instrument in the top centre position.
classification_reason: Uses ‚Äúmust‚Äù to obligate where the direction-of-flight instrument is placed, so it is a binding requirement.

text: (c) Required powerplant instruments must be closely grouped on th e instrument panel. In addition  ‚Äì
classification_reason: Says powerplant instruments ‚Äúmust be closely grouped,‚Äù imposing a direct obligation.

text: (1) The location of identical powerplant instruments fo r the engines must prevent confusion as to which engine each instrument relates; and
classification_reason: Requires that identical engine instruments be arranged to avoid confusion, stated with ‚Äúmust,‚Äù hence mandatory.

text: (2) Powerplant instruments vital to the safe operation of the aeroplane must be plainly visible to the appropriate crewmembers.
classification_reason: Uses ‚Äúmust‚Äù to demand that critical powerplant instruments be visible, making it an enforceable rule.

text: (d) Instrument panel vibration may not dama ge or impair the accuracy of any instrument.
classification_reason: Prohibits panel vibration from harming instruments (‚Äúmay not‚Äù), setting a compulsory performance limit.

text: (e) If a visual indicator is provided to indicate malfunction of an instrument, it must be effective under all probable cockpit lighting conditions.
classification_reason: States that any malfunction indicator provided ‚Äúmust be effective‚Äù under all lighting, creating a mandatory requirement.

text: (See [REF: AMC 25.1322] )
classification_reason: It only points the reader to AMC 25.1322 and contains no obligation or scope statement.

text: (a) Flight crew alerts must:
classification_reason: Uses ‚Äúmust‚Äù to state what flight-crew alerts are required to do.

text: (1) provide the flight crew with the information needed to:
classification_reason: Contains the verb ‚Äúprovide‚Äù tied to the subject ‚Äòflight crew alerts‚Äô, creating a mandatory action.

text: (i) identify non -normal operation or aeroplane system conditions, and
classification_reason: Lists an item that completes the sentence in (a)(1) but has no independent verb.

text: (ii)  determine the appropriate actions, if any;
classification_reason: Second list item finishing the requirement in (a)(1) without its own verb.

text: (2) be readily and easily detectable and intelligible by the flight crew under all foreseeable operating conditions, including conditions where multiple alerts are provided;
classification_reason: States that alerts ‚Äòmust be‚Äô detectable and intelligible, containing its own obligation.

text: (3) be removed when the alerting condition no longer exists.
classification_reason: Requires alerts to ‚Äòbe removed‚Äô when the condition ends, a clear must-statement.

text: (b) Alerts must conform to the following priori tisation hierarchy based on the urgency of flight crew awareness and response:
classification_reason: Uses ‚Äúmust conform‚Äù to impose a hierarchy requirement on alerts.

text: (1) Warning: For conditions that require immediate flight crew awareness and immediate flight crew response.
classification_reason: Defines the first hierarchy level without its own verb, completing the requirement in (b).

text: (2) Caution: For conditions that require immediate flight crew aware ness and subsequent flight crew response.
classification_reason: Second descriptive bullet under the hierarchy with no independent verb.

text: (3) Advisory: For conditions that require flight crew awareness and may require subsequent flight crew response.
classification_reason: Third descriptive bullet completing the list in (b) without its own verb.

text: (c) Warning and Caution alerts must:
classification_reason: States that warning and caution alerts ‚Äòmust‚Äô meet further criteria.

text: (1) be prioritised within each category, when necessary;
classification_reason: Uses ‚Äòbe prioritised‚Äô tied to the alerts, creating a specific mandatory action.

text: (2) provide timely attention -getting cues through at least two different senses by a combination of aural, visual, or tactile indications;
classification_reason: Requires alerts to ‚Äòprovide‚Äô cues through multiple senses, containing its own verb.

text: (3) permit each occurrence of the attention -getting cues required by sub -paragraph (c)(2) to be acknowledg ed and suppressed, unless they are required to be continuous.
classification_reason: Mandates that cues can be acknowledged and suppressed, a direct obligation.

text: (d) The alert function must be designed to minimise the effects of false and nuisance alerts. In particular, it must be designed to:
classification_reason: Says the alert function ‚Äòmust be designed‚Äô to minimise false or nuisance alerts.

text: (1) prevent the presentation of an alert when it is inappropr iate or unnecessary;
classification_reason: Requires the system to ‚Äòprevent‚Äô inappropriate alerts, containing its own verb.

text: (2) provide a means to suppress an attention -getting component of an alert caused by a failure of the alerting function that interferes with the flight crew‚Äôs ability to safely operate the aeroplane. This means must not be readily avai lable to the flight crew so that it could be operated inadvertently or by habitual reflexive action. When an alert is suppressed, there must be a clear and unmistakable annunciation to the flight crew that the alert has been suppressed.
classification_reason: Obliges the system to ‚Äòprovide‚Äô a suppression means, a clear must-statement.

text: (e) Visual alert in dications must:
classification_reason: States that visual alert indications ‚Äòmust‚Äô meet the listed criteria.

text: (1) conform to the following colour convention:
classification_reason: Requires indications to ‚Äòconform‚Äô to a colour convention, using an imperative verb.

text: (i) Red for Warning alert indications.
classification_reason: Lists the prescribed colour for warnings without its own verb.

text: (ii) Amber or yellow for Caution alert indications.
classification_reason: Lists the prescribed colour for cautions and has no independent verb.

text: (iii)  Any colour except red or green for Advisory alert indications.
classification_reason: Lists the permissible colour for advisories, again lacking its own verb.

text: (2) use visual coding technique s, together with other alerting function elements on the flight deck, to distinguish between Warning, Caution and Advisory alert indications, if they are presented on monochromatic displays that are incapable of conforming to the colour convention in parag raph (e)(1).
classification_reason: Mandates use of visual coding techniques; contains the verb ‚Äòuse‚Äô as a requirement.

text: (f) Use of the colours red, amber and yellow on the flight deck for functions other than flight crew alerting must be limited and must not adversely affect flight crew alerting.
classification_reason: Uses ‚Äòmust be limited‚Äô and ‚Äòmust not adversely affect‚Äô to impose binding rules on colour use.

text: (See [REF: AMC 25.1323]) For each airspeed indicating system, the following apply:
classification_reason: States that the subsequent rules apply to every airspeed indicating system but gives no standalone obligation itself.

text: Each airspeed indicating instrument must be approved and must be calibrated to indicate true airspeed (at sea -level with a standard a tmosphere) with a minimum practicable instrument calibration error when the corresponding pitot and static pressures are applied.
classification_reason: Uses the word "must" to require approval and calibration of each airspeed indicator.

text: Each system must be calibrated to determine the system error (that is, the relation between IAS and CAS) in flight and dur ing the accelerated takeoff ground run. The ground run calibration must be determined ‚Äì
classification_reason: Requires each system to be calibrated and sets conditions for the ground-run calibration.

text: From 0¬∑8 of the minimum value of V 1, to the maximum value of V 2, considering the approved ranges of altitude and weight; and
classification_reason: Provides a range of speeds completing the calibration requirement but has no independent verb.

text: With the wing -flaps and power setti ngs corresponding to the values determined in the establishment of the take -off path under CS 25.111  assuming that the critical engine fails at the minimum value of V 1.
classification_reason: Adds flap and power settings to the calibration context without introducing its own obligation.

text: The airspeed error of the installation, excluding the airspeed indicator instrument  calibration error, may not exceed 3% or five knots, whichever is greater, t hroughout the speed range, from  ‚Äì
classification_reason: Sets a maximum allowable airspeed error, using the prohibitive phrase "may not exceed."

text: VMO to 1¬∑23 V SR1 with wing -flaps  retracted; and
classification_reason: Lists the first speed range that qualifies the error limit, lacking its own mandatory verb.

text: 1¬∑23 VS R0 to V FE with wing -flaps in the landing position.
classification_reason: Lists the second speed range qualifying the error limit, without an independent verb.

text: From 1¬∑23 V SR to the speed at which stall warning begins, the IAS must change perceptibly with CAS and in the same sense, and at speeds below stall warning speed the IAS must not change in an incorrect sense. (See [REF: AMC 25.1323(d)] .)

text: Unpressurised aeroplanes . Evacuate the static pressure system to a pressure differential of approximately 33.86 HPa, (1 inch of mercury) or to a reading on the altimeter, 305 m (1 000 ft) above the aeroplane elevation at the time of the test. Without additional pumping for a period of 1 minute, the loss of indicated altitude must not exceed 30 m (100 ft) on the altimeter.
classification_reason: Gives compulsory test steps and a ‚Äòmust not exceed‚Äô limit, both of which impose direct obligations.

text: Pressurised aeroplanes . Evacuate the static pressure system until pressure differential equivalent to the maximum cabin pressure differential for which the aeroplane is type certificated is achieved. Without additional pumping for a period of 1 minute, the loss of indicated altitude must not exceed 2% of the equivalent altitude of the maximum cabin differential pressure or 30 m (100 ft), whichever is greater.
classification_reason: Specifies mandatory test conditions and limits, using ‚Äòmust not exceed‚Äô, thus imposing enforceable requirements.

text: Each pressure altimeter must be approved and must be calibrated to indicate pressure altitude in a standard atmosphere, with a minimum practicable calibration error when the corresponding static pressures are applied.

text: Each system must be designed and installed so that the error in indicated pressure altitude, at sea-level, with a standard atmosphere, excluding instrument calibration error, does not result in an error of more than ¬±9 m (¬±30 ft) per 185 km/hr (100 knots) speed for the appropriate configuration in the speed range between 1¬∑23 V SR0 with wing -flaps extended and 1¬∑7 V SR1 with wing -flaps retracted. However, the error need not be less than ¬±9 m (¬±30 ft).

text: If an altimeter system is fitted with a device that provides corrections to the altimeter indication, the device must be designed and installed in such manner that it can be bypassed when it malfunctions, unless an alternate altimeter system is provided. text: Each magnetic direction indicator must be installed so that its accuracy is not excessively affected by the aeroplane‚Äôs vibration or magnetic fields.

text: The magnetic direction indicator required by [REF: CS 25.1303(a)(3)] may not have a deviation, after compensation, in normal level flight, greater than 10 degrees on any heading.

text: (See [REF: AMC No. 1 to CS 25.1329] [REF: AMC No. 2 to CS 25.1329] )
classification_reason: This is the section heading; it simply establishes that the following rules concern the flight-guidance/autopilot system but imposes no action itself.

text: (a) Quick disengagement controls for the autopilot and autothrust functions must be provided for each pilot. The autopilot quick disengagement controls must be located on both control wheels (or equivalent). The autothrust quick disengagement controls must be located on the thrust control lev ers. Quick disengagement controls must be readily accessible to each pilot while operating the control wheel (or equivalent) and thrust control levers.
classification_reason: Uses ‚Äúmust‚Äù to require specific quick-disengage controls and their locations, creating a binding obligation for designers.

text: (b) The effects of a failure of the system to disengage the autopilot or autothrust functions when manua lly commanded by the pilot must be assessed in accordance with the specifications of [REF: CS 25.1309] .
classification_reason: Requires failure effects to be assessed per CS 25.1309, stating an explicit obligation with ‚Äúmust be assessed.‚Äù

text: (c) Engagement or switching of the flight guidance system, a mode, or a sensor must not produce a transient response affecting the control or flight path of th e aeroplane any greater than a minor transient.
classification_reason: Mandates that engaging or switching the system must not generate more than a minor transient, clearly an enforceable requirement.

text: (d) Under normal conditions, the disengagement of any automatic control functions of a flight guidance system must not produce a transient response affecting the control or flight path of the aeroplane any gr eater than a minor transient.
classification_reason: Specifies that disengagement under normal conditions must not cause more than a minor transient, using ‚Äúmust not,‚Äù hence mandatory.

text: (e) Under rare -normal or non -normal conditions, the disengagement of any automatic control functions of a flight guidance system must not produce a transient response affecting the control or flight path of the aeroplane any g reater than a significant transient.
classification_reason: Sets a binding limit on transients under rare-normal or non-normal conditions, again employing ‚Äúmust not.‚Äù

text: (f) The function and direction of motion of each command reference control (e.g., heading select, vertical speed) must be readily apparent or plainly indicated on, or adjacent to, each control if necessary to prevent in appropriate use or confusion .
classification_reason: Obliges that command reference controls be clearly identifiable, using ‚Äúmust‚Äù to impose the duty.

text: (g) Under any condition of flight appropriate to its use, the flight guidance system must not: ‚Äî produce unacceptable loads on the aeroplane (in accordance with [REF: CS 25.302] ), or ‚Äî create hazardous deviations in the flight path. This applies to both fault -free operation and in the event of a malfunction, and assumes that the pilot begins corrective action within a reasonable period of time.
classification_reason: States that the system must not create unacceptable loads or hazardous deviations, a direct mandatory constraint.

text: (h) When the flight guidance system is in use, a means must be provided to avoid excursions beyond an acceptable margin from the speed range of the normal flight envelope. If the aircraft experiences an excursion outside this range, the flight guidance system must not provide guidance or control to an unsafe speed.
classification_reason: Requires means to avoid and limit speed-range excursions while the system is in use, clearly prescriptive.

text: (i) The flight guidance system fun ctions, controls, indications, and alerts must be designed to minimise flight crew errors and confusion concerning the behaviour and operation of the flight guidance system. Means must be provided to indicate the current mode of operation, including any ar med modes, transitions, and reversions.  Selector switch position is not an acceptable means of indication. The controls and indications must be grouped and presented in a logical and consistent manner. The indications must be visible to each pilot under a ll expected lighting conditions.
classification_reason: Mandates design features to minimise crew error and show current modes, using ‚Äúmust be designed‚Äù ‚Äì a compulsory design rule.

text: (j) Following disengagement of the autopilot, a warning (visual and aural) must be provided to each pilot and be timely and distinct from all other cockpit warnings.
classification_reason: Demands a timely, distinct autopilot disengagement warning, expressed with binding language.

text: (k) Following disengagement of the autothrust function, a  caution must be provided to each pilot.
classification_reason: Requires a caution after autothrust disengagement, making it a clear obligation.

text: (l) The autopilot must not create an unsafe condition when the flight crew applies an override force to the flight controls.
classification_reason: States that the autopilot must not create an unsafe condition during manual override, imposing a mandatory safety requirement.

text: (m) During autothrust operation, it must be possible for the flight crew to move the thrus t levers without requiring excessive force. The autothrust response to flight crew override must not create an unsafe condition.
classification_reason: Specifies forces and behaviour during autothrust override, using ‚Äúmust‚Äù to establish an enforceable requirement.

text: (a) For each instrument required by [REF: CS 25.1303(b)]  that uses a power supply, the following apply:
classification_reason: This opening sentence simply states that the subsequent sub-paragraphs apply to every powered instrument; it does not itself impose a technical obligation.

text: (1) Each instrument must have a visual  means integral with the instrument, to indicate when power adequate to sustain proper instrument performance is not being supplied. The power must be measured at or near the point where it enters the instruments. For electric instruments, the power is con sidered to be adequate when the voltage is within approved limits.
classification_reason: Uses the word ‚Äúmust‚Äù to require each instrument to include a visual indication of inadequate power, making it a binding rule.

text: (2) Each instrument must, in the event of the failure of one power source, be supplied by another power source. This may be accomplished automatically or by manual means. The failure of one  power source must not affect the same instrument of both pilot stations.
classification_reason: States that instruments must be powered by another source upon failure of one source, clearly imposing an obligation.

text: (3) If an instrument presenting flight and/or navigation data receives information from sources external to that instrument and loss of that information would render the presented da ta unreliable, a clear and unambiguous visual warning must be given to the crew when such loss of information occurs that the presented data should not be relied upon. The indication must be incorporated in the instrument.

text: (b) As used in this paragraph, ‚Äòi nstrument‚Äô includes devices that are physically contained in one unit, and devices that are composed of two or more physically separate units or components connected together (such as a remote indicating gyroscopic direction indicator that includes a magne tic sensing element, a gyroscopic unit, an amplifier, and an indicator connected together).

text: If two independent sources of electrical po wer for particular equipment or systems are required for certification, or by operating rules, in the event of the failure of one power source for such equipment or system, another power source  (including its separate feeder) must be automatically provided  or be manually selectable to maintain equipment or system operation. (See [REF: AMC 25.1355(c)]  and [REF: AMC 25.1310(a)] .)
classification_reason: Uses the word 'must' to mandate that an alternate power source be available when two independent sources are required.

text: (See  [REF: AMC 25.1357])
classification_reason: This line only tells the reader to look at AMC 25.1357 and contains no rule itself.

text: Automatic protective devices must be used to minimise distress to the electrical system and hazard to the aeroplane in the event of wiring faults or serious malfunction of the system or connected equipment. (See [REF: AMC 25.1357(a)] .)
classification_reason: It uses the verb ‚Äúmust‚Äù to require automatic protective devices to limit system distress and hazards.

text: The p rotective and control devices in the generating system must be designed to de -energise and disconnect faulty power sources and power transmission equipment from their associated busses with sufficient rapidity to provide protection from hazardous over -voltage and other malfunctioning.
classification_reason: It mandates that protective and control devices disconnect faulty power sources quickly.

text: Each re -settable circuit protective device must be designed so that, when an overload or circuit fault exists, it will open the circuit irrespective of the position of the operating control.
classification_reason: It requires resettable devices to open the circuit automatically when a fault exists.

text: If the ability to reset a circuit breaker or replace a fuse is essential to safety in flight, that circuit breaker or fuse must be located and identified so that it can be readily reset or replaced in flight. Where fuses are used, there must be spare fuses for use in -flight  equal to at least 50% of the number of fuses of each rating required for complete circuit protection.
classification_reason: It states that breakers or fuses essential for flight safety must be reachable and spare fuses carried.

text: Each circuit for essential loads must have individual circuit protection. However, individual protection for each circuit in an essential load system  (such as each position light circuit in a system) is not required.
classification_reason: It obliges individual circuit protection for essential loads while allowing a limited exception.

text: For aeroplane systems for which the ability to remove or reset power during normal operations is necessary, the system must be designed so that circuit breakers are not the primary mea ns to remove or reset system power, unless specifically designed for use as a switch. (see [REF: AMC 25.1357(f)] ).
classification_reason: It requires that circuit breakers not be the primary means to switch power unless designed for it.

text: Automatic reset circuit breakers may be used as integral protectors for electrical equipment (such as thermal cutouts) if there is circuit prote ction to protect the cable to the equipment.
classification_reason: It permits automatic-reset breakers only if other protection exists for the wiring.

text: (See [REF: AMC 25.1360])
classification_reason: This line only points readers to associated AMC material and contains no requirement or applicability statement.

text: Shock . The electrical system must be designed so as to minimise the risk of electric shock to crew, passengers and servicing personnel and also to maintenance personnel using normal precautions. (See [REF: AMC 25.1360(a)]  and [REF: CS 25.899] .)
classification_reason: States that the electrical system 'must be designed' to minimise electric shock risk, setting a binding obligation.

text: Burns . The temperature of  any part, which has to be handled during normal operation by the flight crew, must not be such as to cause dangerous inadvertent movement, or injury to the crewmember. (See [REF: AMC 25.1360(b)] .)
classification_reason: Requires that component temperature 'must not be such as to cause' injury, imposing a clear design obligation.

text: (See [REF: AMC 25.1362] ) A suitable supply must be provided to those services, which are required, in order that emergency procedures may be carried out, after an emergency landing or ditching. The circuits for these services must be so designed, protected and installed such that the risk of their causing a fire, under these conditions, is minimised.
classification_reason: It uses mandatory wording 'must be provided' and 'must be designed' to set binding design obligations for emergency power and circuit safety.

text: (See [REF: AMC 25.1363] )
classification_reason: The paragraph is only a header followed by a parenthetical cross-reference to AMC 25.1363 and contains no rule itself.

text: Tests must be made to determine that the performance of the electrical supply systems me ets the requirements of this CS -25 under all the appropriate normal and failure  conditions. When laboratory tests of the electrical system are conducted ‚Äì
classification_reason: It states that tests must be made to verify the electrical supply system, imposing an obligatory action.

text: The tests must be performed on a mock -up using the same generating equipment used in the aeroplane;
classification_reason: It requires that the tests be performed on a mock-up using the same generating equipment, using the word 'must'.

text: The equipment must simulate the electrical characteristics of the distri bution wiring and connected loads to the extent necessary for valid test results; and
classification_reason: It obliges that the equipment simulate wiring and loads to obtain valid results, again using 'must'.

text: Laboratory generator drives must simulate the actual prime movers on the aeroplane with respect to their reaction to generator loading, including loading due to fault s.
classification_reason: It mandates that laboratory generator drives simulate actual prime movers with respect to loading, containing a clear 'must'.

text: For each flight condition that cannot be simulated adequately in the laboratory or by ground tests on the aeroplane, flight tests must be made.
classification_reason: It requires flight tests for conditions not adequately simulated on ground, expressing a binding obligation.

text: (See [REF: AMC 25.1365] )
classification_reason: This standalone note only points the reader to AMC 25.1365 and contains no rule of its own.

text: Domestic appliances must be s o designed and installed that in the event of failures of the electrical supply or control system, the requirements of [REF: CS 25.1309(b)] and [REF: CS 25.1309(c)] will be satisfied.
classification_reason: It uses ‚Äúmust‚Äù to obligate how domestic appliances must be designed and installed to meet 25.1309(b) and (c).

text: The installation of galleys and cooking appliances must be such as to minimise the risk of overheat , fire, burns, or spilled liquids to the aeroplane, passengers, and crew (See [REF: AMC 25.1365(b)]).
classification_reason: It states that galley and cooking appliance installations "must" minimise certain hazards, imposing a binding requirement.

text: Domestic appliances, particularly those in galley areas, must be so installed or protected as to prevent damage or contamination of other equipment or  systems from fluids or vapours which may be present during normal operation or as a result of spillage, where such damage or contamination may hazard the aeroplane.
classification_reason: It mandates that appliances "must" be installed or protected to avoid damaging other equipment, creating an enforceable obligation.

text: Unless it can be shown that compliance with [REF: CS 25.1309(b)]  is provided by the circuit p rotective device required by [REF: CS 25.1357(a)] , electric motors and transformers etc. (including those installed in domestic systems, such as galleys and toilet flush systems) must be provided with a suitable thermal protection device if necessary to prevent t hem overheating such as to create a smoke or fire hazard under normal operation and failure conditions.
classification_reason: Despite the introductory 'unless' condition, the clause ultimately states appliances "must" have thermal protection, setting a clear requirement engineers must satisfy.

text: The instrument lights must ‚Äì
classification_reason: Paragraph (a) states that instrument lights "must" meet certain criteria, creating a binding obligation.

text: Provide sufficient illumination to make each instrument, switch and other device necessary for safe operation easily readable unless suffic ient illumination is available from another source; and

text: Be installed so that ‚Äì

text: No objectionable reflections are visible to the pilot.
classification_reason: Sub-item (ii) is another detailed condition under (2) that relies on the parent "must" and has no separate mandate.

text: Unless undimmed instrument lights are satisfactory under each expected flight condition, there must be a means to control the intensity of illumination.
classification_reason: Paragraph (b) sets a rule using "there must be" requiring a means to control illumination, establishing a clear obligation.

text: (a) Each landing light must be approved, and must be installed so that ‚Äì
classification_reason: States that each landing light must be approved and installed in a certain way, using the obligatory word ‚Äúmust.‚Äù

text: (1) No objectionabl e glare is visible to  the pilot;
classification_reason: Item (1) completes the installation requirement by describing a condition (no glare) but carries no independent ‚Äòmust.‚Äô

text: (2) The pilot is not adversely affected by halation; and
classification_reason: Like (1), this list item specifies a condition (no halation effect) that flows from the parent obligation.

text: (3) It provides enough light for night landing.
classification_reason: Third list item sets another condition (enough light for night landing) without its own independent verb of obligation.

text: (b) Except when one switch is used for the lights of a multiple light installation at one location, there must be a s eparate switch for each light.
classification_reason: Contains an explicit ‚Äòmust‚Äô stating the need for separate switches, creating a direct obligation despite an internal exception phrase.

text: (c) There must be a means to indicate to the pilots when the landing lights are extended.
classification_reason: Requires a means to indicate landing-light extension, using the mandatory term ‚Äúmust,‚Äù hence a binding requirement.

text: (a) General . Each part of each position light system must meet the applicable requirements of this paragraph and each system as a whole must meet the requirements of [REF: CS 25.1387]  to [REF: CS 25.1397] .
classification_reason: Uses the word ‚Äúmust‚Äù to obligate that every part and the whole system meet specified rules, telling engineers what they have to do.

text: (b) Forward position lights . Forward position lights must consist of a red and  a green light spaced laterally as far apart as practicable and installed forward on the aeroplane so that, with the aeroplane in the normal flying position, the red light is on the left side, and the green light is on the right side. Each light must be ap proved.
classification_reason: States that forward position lights must have defined colours, placement and approval, imposing direct obligations.

text: (c) Rear position light.  The rear position light must be a white light mounted as far aft as practicable on the tail or on each wing tip, and must be approved.
classification_reason: Requires the rear position light to be white, aft-mounted, and approved, clearly mandating compliance.

text: (d) Light covers and colour filters.  Each light cover or colour filter must be at leas t flame resistant and may not change colour or shape or lose any appreciable light transmission during normal use.
classification_reason: Mandates flame resistance and stable performance of light covers/filters, giving a binding rule engineers must satisfy.

text: (a) Except as provided in sub -paragraph (e) of this paragraph, each forward and rear position light must, as installed, show unbroken light within the dihedral angles described in this paragraph.
classification_reason: States that the lights ‚Äúmust‚Ä¶ show unbroken light,‚Äù imposing a binding obligation on the design except where paragraph (e) applies.

text: (b) Dihedral angle L (left) is formed by two intersecting vertical planes, the first parallel to the longitudinal axis of the ae roplane, and the other at 110 ¬∞ to the left of the first, as viewed when looking forward along the longitudinal axis.
classification_reason: Explains what the left dihedral angle ‚ÄòL‚Äô is by describing the two planes that form it.

text: (c) Dihedral angle R (right) is formed by two intersecting vertical planes, the first parallel to the longitudinal axis of the aeroplane, a nd the other at 110 ¬∞ to the right of the first, as viewed when looking forward along the longitudinal axis.
classification_reason: Defines the right dihedral angle ‚ÄòR‚Äô by describing the intersecting planes that establish it.

text: (d) Dihedral angle A (aft) is formed by two intersecting vertical planes making angles of 70 o to the right and to the left, respectively, to a vert ical plane passing through the longitudinal axis, as viewed when looking aft along the longitudinal axis.
classification_reason: Defines the aft dihedral angle ‚ÄòA‚Äô through a geometric description of intersecting planes.

text: (e) If the rear position light when mounted as far aft as practicable in accordance with [REF: CS 25.1385(c)] , cannot show unbroken light within dihedral angle A (as defined in sub -paragraph (d) of this paragraph), a solid angle or angles of obstructed visibility tot alling not more than 0¬∑04 steradians is allowable within that dihedral angle, if such solid angle is within a cone whose apex is at the rear position light and whose elements make an angle of 30 o with a vertical line passing through the rear position ligh t.
classification_reason: Provides an allowance that limits the strict requirement in (a), specifying when and how obstruction is permitted.

text: General . The intensities prescribed in this paragraph must be provided by new equipment with light covers and colour filters in place. Intensities must be determined with  the light source operating at a steady value equal to the average luminous output of the source at the normal operating voltage of the aeroplane. The light distribution and intensity of each position light must meet the requirements of sub -paragraph (b) o f this paragraph.
classification_reason: Uses the verb ‚Äúmust‚Äù to prescribe how intensities are to be determined and what performance the lights have to achieve.

text: Forward and rear position lights.  The light distribution and intensities of forward and rear position lights must be expressed in terms of minimum intensities in the horizontal plane, minimum intensities in any vertical plane, and ma ximum intensities in overlapping beams, within dihedral angles L, R and A, and must meet the following requirements:
classification_reason: States that forward and rear position lights ‚Äúmust‚Äù meet specified intensity expressions, imposing a binding obligation.

text: Intensities in the horizontal plane.  Each intensity in the horizontal plane (the plane containing the longitudinal axis of the aeropla ne and perpendicular to the plane of symmetry of the aeroplane) must equal or exceed the values in [REF: CS 25.1391] .
classification_reason: Requires that each horizontal-plane intensity ‚Äúmust equal or exceed‚Äù certain values, making it a direct rule.

text: Intensities in any vertical plane.  Each intensity in any vertical plane (the plane perpendicular to the horizontal plane) must equal or exce ed the appropriate value in [REF: CS 25.1393] , where I is the minimum intensity prescribed in [REF: CS 25.1391]  for the corresponding angles in the horizontal plane.

text: Intensities in overlaps between adjacent signals.  No intensity in any overlap between adjacent sign als may exceed the values given in [REF: CS 25.1395] , except that higher intensities in overlaps may be used with main beam intensities substantially greater than the minima specified in [REF: CS 25.1391]  and [REF: 25.1393] if the overlap intensities in relation to the main be am intensities do not adversely affect signal clarity. text: General . The aeroplane must have an anticollision light system that ‚Äì

text: Consists of one or more approved anti -collision lights located so that their light will not impair the crew‚Äôs vision or detract from the conspicuity of the position lights; and
classification_reason: Item (1) is part of the main obligation in (a) and specifies what the system must consist of, but relies on the parent sentence for the verb 'must'.

text: Meets the requirements of sub -paragraphs (b) to (f) of this paragraph.

text: Field of coverage . The system must consist of enough light to illuminate the vital areas around the aeroplane considering the physical co nfiguration and flight characteristics of the aeroplane. The field of coverage must extend in ea ch direction within at least 75 ¬∞ above and 75 ¬∞ below the horizontal plane of the aeroplane, except that a solid angle or angles of obstructed visibility totalling not more than 0¬∑03 steradians is allowable within a solid angle equal to 0¬∑15 steradians centred about the longitudinal axis in the rearwar d direction.
classification_reason: Gives its own rule that the system must provide a specified field of coverage, using the word ‚Äúmust.‚Äù

text: Flashing characteristics . The arrangement of the system, that is, the number of light sources, beam width, speed of rotation, and other characteristics, must give an effective flash frequency of not less than 40, nor more than 100 cycles per minute. The effective flash frequency is the frequency at which the aeroplane‚Äôs complete anti -collision light system is observed from a distance, and applies to each section of light including any overlaps that exist when the system consists of more th an one light source. In overlaps, flash frequencies may exceed 100, but not 180 cycles per minute.
classification_reason: Requires the flash frequency to be within a given range, containing its own subject and the mandatory verb 'must'.

text: Colour . Each anti -collision light must be either aviation red or aviation white and must meet the applicable requirements of [REF: CS 25.1397] .
classification_reason: Mandates the colour of each light and references standards, employing the obligatory word 'must'.

text: (see [REF: AMC 25.1403] ) Unless operations at night in known or forecast icing conditions are prohibited by an operating limitation, a means must be provided for illuminating or otherwise determining the formation of ice on the parts of the wings that are critical from the standpoint of ice accumulation. Any illumination that is used must be of a type that will not cause glare or reflection that would handicap crewmembers in the performance of their duties.
classification_reason: The paragraph uses the word ‚Äúmust‚Äù twice to impose design obligations (provide means to detect ice and ensure lighting does not create glare), so it states binding requirements engineers have to meet.

text: (a) Accessibility . Required safety equipment to be used by the crew in an emergency must be readily accessible.
classification_reason: It states that safety equipment "must be" readily accessible, imposing a clear obligation.

text: (b) Stowage provisions . Stowage provisions for required emergency equipment must be furnished and must ‚Äì
classification_reason: It says stowage provisions "must be furnished" and sets up further mandatory details.

text: (1) Be arranged so that the equipment is directly acce ssible and its location is obvious; and
classification_reason: This item finishes the verb phrase from (b); it has no independent subject-verb, just adds a required arrangement.

text: (2) Protect the safety equipment from inadvertent damage.
classification_reason: Like (b)(1), it completes the parent 'must' sentence by listing another required feature.

text: (c) Emergency exit descent device . The stowage provisions for the emergency exit descent device required by [REF: CS 25.810(a)]  must be at the exits for which they a re intended.
classification_reason: It tells where the descent device stowage "must be," giving a direct obligation.

text: (d) Liferafts
classification_reason: This is only a heading ('Liferafts') that introduces the subject of the following rules.

text: (1) The stowage provisions for the liferafts described in [REF: CS 25.1415]  must accommodate enough rafts for the maximum number of occupants for which certification for ditching is requested.
classification_reason: It requires that liferaft stowage "must accommodate" enough rafts, a binding rule.

text: (2) Life rafts must be stowed near exits through which the rafts can be launched during an unplanned ditching.
classification_reason: It mandates that liferafts "must be stowed" near suitable exits.

text: (3) Rafts automatically or remotely released outside the aeroplane must be attached to the aeroplane by means of the static line prescribed in [REF: CS 25.1415] .
classification_reason: It obliges that certain rafts "must be attached" by a static line.

text: (4) The stowage provisions for each portable life raft must allow rapid detachment and removal of the raft for use at other than  the intended exits.
classification_reason: It requires stowage to "must allow" rapid detachment, imposing a direct obligation.

text: (e) Long -range signalling device . The stowage provisions for the long -range signalling device required by [REF: CS 25.1415]  must be near an exit available during an unplanned ditching.
classification_reason: It specifies where the signalling device stowage "must be," setting a mandatory condition.

text: (f) Life-preserver stowage provisions . The stowage provi sions for life preservers described in [REF: CS 25.1415]  must accommodate one life preserver for each occupant for which certification for ditching is requested. Each life preserver must be within easy reach of each seated occupant.
classification_reason: Both sentences use "must," setting compulsory provisions for life-preserver stowage and reach.

text: (g) Life line stowage provisi ons. If certification for ditching under [REF: CS 25.801]  is requested, there must be provisions to store the lifelines. These provisions must ‚Äì
classification_reason: It states there "must be" lifeline stowage provisions and introduces further mandatory sub-items.

text: (1) Allow one life line to be attached to each side of the fuselage; and
classification_reason: This list item completes the main 'must' clause by describing what the provisions shall allow.

text: (2) Be arranged to allow the lifelines to be  used to enable the occupants to stay on the wing after ditching. This requirement is not applicable to aeroplanes having no over -wing ditching exits.
classification_reason: It continues the list under the existing 'must,' giving another required arrangement and noting a limited exception.

text: Ditching equipment used in aeroplanes to be certified for ditching under [REF: CS 25.801] , and required by the Operating Rules, must meet the requirements of this paragraph.
classification_reason: It states that ditching equipment "must meet" the paragraph‚Äôs requirements, imposing an obligation.

text: Each lifer aft and each life preserver must be approved. In addition ‚Äì
classification_reason: It commands that each liferaft and life preserver "must be approved," creating a binding requirement.

text: Unless excess rafts of enough capacity are provided, the buoyancy and seating capacity beyond the rated capacity of the rafts must accommodate all occupants of the aeroplane in the event of a loss of one raft of the largest rated capacity; and
classification_reason: It requires capacity that "must accommodate" all occupants if a raft is lost, setting a mandatory performance rule.

text: Each raft must have a trailing line, and must have a static line designed to hold the raft near the aeroplane but to release it if the aeroplane becomes totally submerged.
classification_reason: It mandates that each raft "must have" specific lines, establishing a compulsory design feature.

text: Approved survival equipm ent must be attached to, or stored adjacent to, each liferaft.
classification_reason: It obliges that survival equipment "must be attached to, or stored adjacent to," each liferaft.

text: There must be an approved survival type emergency locator transmitter for use in one life raft.
classification_reason: It specifies that there "must be" an approved emergency locator transmitter, imposing a requirement.

text: For aeroplanes, not certificated for ditching under [REF: CS 25.801]  and not having approved life preservers, there must be an approved flotation means for each occupant. This means must be within easy reach of each seated occupant and must be readily removable from the aeroplane.
classification_reason: It dictates that certain aeroplanes "must" provide an approved flotation means within reach, hence a binding rule.

text: (See [REF: AMC 25.1419] ) If the applicant seeks certification for flight in icing conditions, the aeroplane must be able to safely operate in the continuous maximum and intermittent maximum icing conditions of Appendix C . To establish this‚Äì
classification_reason: States that aircraft seeking icing approval must be able to operate safely in specified icing conditions, using the obligatory word ‚Äúmust.‚Äù

text: (a) An analysi s must be performed to establish that the ice protection for the various components of the aeroplane is adequate, taking into account the various aeroplane operational configurations; and
classification_reason: Requires that an analysis be performed, containing its own subject and the word ‚Äúmust.‚Äù

text: (b) To verify the ice protection analysis, to check for icing anomalies, and to demonstrate that the ice protection system and its components are effective, the aeroplane or its components must be flight tested in the various operational configurations, in measured natural atmospheric icing conditions, and as found n ecessary, by one or more of the following means:
classification_reason: Mandates flight testing to verify the analysis, using ‚Äúmust‚Äù and standing alone as a full requirement.

text: (1) Laboratory dry air or simulated icing tests, or a combination of both, of the components or models of the components.
classification_reason: Provides one permissible test method without its own verb; it completes the requirement in (b).

text: (2) Flight dry air tests of the ice protection system as a whole, or of its individua l components.

text: (1) A complete pneumatic system must be static tested to show that it can withstand a pressure of 1¬∑5 times the working pressure without a deformation of  any part of the system that would prevent it from performing its intended function. text: (2) The entire system or appropriate sub -systems must be tested in an aeroplane or in a mock -up installation to determine proper performance and proper relation  to other aeroplane systems. Endurance tests must simulate the repeated complete flights that could be expected to occur in service. Elements which fail during the tests must be modified in order to have the design deficiency corrected and, where necessary, must be sufficiently retested. text: The equipment must supply protective oxygen of 15 minutes duration per crew member at a pressure altitude of 2438 m (8000 ft) with a respiratory minute volume of 30 litres per minute BTPD. The equipment and system must be designed to prevent any inward leakage to the inside of the device  and prevent any outward leakage causing any significant increase in the oxygen content of the local ambient atmosphere. If a demand oxygen system is used, a sup ply of 300 litres of free oxygen at 21¬∞C (70¬∞F) and 760 mm Hg pressure is considered to be of 15 -minute duration at the prescribed altitude and minute volume. If a continuous flow open circuit protective breathing system is used a flow rate of 60 litres pe r minute at 2438 m (8 000 ft) (45 litres per minute at sea level) and a supply of 600 litres of free oxygen at 21¬∞C (70¬∞F) and 204 kPa (760 mm Hg) pressure is considered to be of 15 -minute duration at the prescribed altitude and minute volume. Continuous f low systems must not increase the ambient oxygen content of the local atmosphere above that of demand systems. BTPD refers to body temperature conditions, that is 37¬∞C (99¬∞F), at ambient pressure, dry.
classification_reason: Specifies oxygen supply performance and leakage limits with repeated "must" language, directing compliance.

text: The equipment must meet the requirements of [REF: CS 25.1441] .
